This is a school that has a president wanting to be an R1 school, but the faculty are led by a provost that is stuck in the 1990s. review_title: University of Memphis: Science Learning Center - Tutor and Supplemental Instructor
job_title: Supplemental Instructor and Science Tutor in Memphis, TN
pros:
The orientation and training required before starting provide essential skills for anyone interested in teaching. This experience taught me many skills such as overcoming barriers in communication, time management, leadership and delegation, and collaborating with professors and colleagues.  
As an hidden bonus, teaching others prepared me for professional entrance exams which I aced!
cons: Due to limited positions and working around class schedules there were many instances that the tutors were overwhelmed with students needing help. This was particularly true towards the end of the semester.

pros: Nice campus, most staff friendly, pay decent for assistant prof's, adding in low cost of living.
cons: Facilities/building in my department are old, cramped for space, no room to move anyone...I had the drum practice room too close to my office, asked them to move it so I could conduct open door student meetings only to be told they would not.  I was lead a bit astray during my interview -> not at all what I thought the position would be. Fellow departmental staff were nice but kept me at a distance. No weekend drinks/bonding  with this bunch

job_title: Financial Services Associate in Memphis, TN
pros: Great work/life balance. Overall great institution to work for. Great benefits for employees.
cons: It is hard to advance. Some people that are in management or key positions of certain departments should be evaluated by both faculty and staff, and they should be held accountable for mistreatment of staff employees in their departments.

review_title: decent but not pretty much stagnant
pros: excellent benefits. job security, work culture mostly depends on your team. lots of sick and paid leave. Other benefits that come with working for a university
cons: salaries are as low as you can imagine. slow moving bureacracy. might be good as a secondary less stressful job and income. Immigrants can forget this place as it doesnot sponspor your permanent residency unless you are tenure track proffessor. All other Universities do this. Lots of crime around. Better not walk anywhere on campus after dark.

pros: Nice campus, good facilities - U of M tends to combine some of the best aspects of a large state school wIith the manageability of a smaller school.
cons: City of Memphis has it's challenges and it's hard to be at the U of M without taking note of them and having some of them have an effect on the faculty/staff.

review_title: Okay, but no raises in 3 years, some challenging students and not-so-good facilities
pros: Good autonomy for faculty in my department, decent support for professional development, okay parking but have to pay, nice new University Center/Student-Union type building, some really good students.
cons: Admission to just about everyone, so some challenging students; no raises in 3 years; not a lot of pride in facilities-- gum all over the ground, dirty parking garage, poorly maintained facilities; some employees on campus act like they're doing you a favor by helping you.

pros: Excellent benefits, vacation and educational opportunities. Insurance benefits used to be better, but they are still pretty good. For salaried employees, it works out to be four weeks of vacation per year plus a week off when the university is closed between Christmas and New Years.
cons: Not many opportunities for advancement unless you have a PhD. Many people have been there for years and years, so the culture is pretty entrenched. Compensation is not competitive. Very low wages.

pros: If you want a month (approx) in accumulated vacation, then this is the place to work. They give 1 sick day and 2 annual days every month. The people I worked with were very "univerisiotic" (very loyal and dedicated).
cons: There are no raises, no personal growth, and no promotions . If all these factors matter to you, then its not a place for you. Its located in Memphis and if you live in Bartlett, it would be a long commute.

job_title: IT Technical Assistant in Memphis, TN
pros:
Supervisors allowed you to do homework or read or whatever so long as you didn't abandon job duties.They also only hire students so as to make it more convenient for them (won't have to make multiple trips between work and classes.) 

The job is a good challenge for people who want to learn how to manage stress under pressure and become more efficient with multitasking or typing. During the beginning of each semester, and especially in the middle of the day, it can be very hectic when working at the phones. The labs are a bit better, but you will still find yourself getting a reasonable workout trying to keep the labs tidy and the printers filled with paper.
cons:
The supervisors can't seem to make up their mind on whether they want to be student-oriented or not. I personally did not mind if they took either the more business-like or student-like strategy, but it seemed like student workers were written up at random whenever they called in absent in advance for school-related problems (either homework or group study,) even when they posted their shift well in advance.

Another issue I see, that is unrelated to the supervisors, is that the ITS budget seems to be getting reduced year by year. For both the Fall and Spring semesters I have been seeing only one person working at the Technology Hub more often than not even if the lab is busy, and the amount of people that arrive to interviews usually fill a classroom computer lab. There are plenty of people who could be willing to work those shifts, but probably did not get hired because of the budget issues. Because of this I feel that the future of ITS isn't going to get much better anytime soon, and it's a shame especially since we have been getting a record amount of new students for the past two semesters.

review_title: Do not take more than 2 years as Visiting xxxx
job_title: Visiting Associate Professor in Memphis, TN
pros: It is growing and the students are nice.
cons: No research support in terms of money. The University does not cover one cent for you attending to at least one conference per year. All the money has to come from you. As visiting, they will not consider you for projects. You are in a bad shape as visiting in any university, avoid having more than two years.   I have been 4 years and I see how is hurting my publication history!@

review_title: An excellent environment to learn and grow
pros: Tuition support for gaining additional skills, Excellent colleagues, Strong sense of purpose, An excellent environment for long term employment or for acquiring the skills to make the jump to your next level, Ample time off for vacation and illness
cons: There's no clear career path for many roles, particularly within staff positions. Professional development (other than coursework) is very basic. There is a silo effect -- departments and colleges do not communicate with one another. Salary is lower than in the private sector

job_title: Research Technician II in Memphis, TN
pros: Engaged colleagues seeking knowledge, exposure to different areas of research, everyday brings new projects and challenges.  Great benefits and hours. Very flexible. Convenience with regard to networking and opportunities.
cons: LOW pay! Not much room for growth or advancement to higher position with more pay. No raises.

review_title: Not a great place to work, but decent, for the most part.
pros: Some parts of the university promote a good work environment (e.g., the Dean's office of Arts and Sciences).  Normal professor perks apply.  Decent salary for a cheap city to live in.
cons: A lot of politics gets in the way of professors moving forward.  Compensation increases are surprisingly small.  Promotions (tenure) is through the normal process and seems mostly fair.

job_title: Desk Assistant At the Living Learning Complex in Memphis, TN
pros: The ability to work on homework or finish other job applications provides one of the greatest incentives for students to apply for this position.
cons: A large standard deviation exists in the quality of service fellow desk assistants demonstrate to the residents. This fact is also true among the immediate supervisors to the desk assistants, the assistant area coordinators.

pros: Benefits are good and can take classes and get reimbursed. There are some really great people that work here.
cons: No accountability and little action from management. Problem employees are retained leaving good employees to find better employment. Very political climate with a lot of favoritism.

pros: Great retirement and insurance benefits as well as payment of tuition at any Tennessee Board of Regents college.
cons: The person I worked for hired me basically to fire me, I believe.  She was very rude and did not train me and did not require her two other employees to train me. I am a somewhat older worker and she kept reminding me of that.

pros: Great benefits, static salary, great for gaining experience
cons: Typical University setting where 10% of the employees do 90% of the work. Additionally, being in the 10% that work very hard doesn't make a bit of difference in regards to salary.

pros: It's good for me but it also depends on the department. For our department, everybody is good. People are friendly and good to each other.
cons: The salary is not good but can afford basic live. You need to choose a good advisor too. Do some research before you do it.

pros: My children get to go to outstanding schools at the university. I can also take a class every semester to further my education. I have a rewarding job where I get to help people.
cons: Heavy workload. Sometimes I’m thrown under the bus when the accountability is not mine. I also have to do some tasks that shouldn’t be mine.

review_title: Small-table thing, just like Calipari said.
pros: High caliber of people on whose talents and resourcefulness those in management rely in order to get things done.
cons: Endless last-minute, short-sighted problem solving approaches by management and administration. They desperately want to be taken seriously on the national stage, but are unwilling to make the progressive, provocative decisions needed to escape their very parochial mindset.

job_title: Student Services Representative in Memphis, TN
pros: Meeting new people, engaging with the students, excellent benefits, and it is a continuous learning environment. The educational benefits are great!
cons: It's hard to be promoted most positions they already have someone in place. Employees stay in the same positions way too long resulting in people not being able to move up.

job_title: Graduate and Teaching Assistant in Montgomery, AL
pros: It was work study and I had such a great advisor that allowed me enough study time. Good opportunity for growth and development as well
cons: There was eventually a need for more experimental techniques to be learnt but we did no have the necessary resources to accomplish that.

review_title: Meaningful work, but lots of silos
pros: It is very meaningful to work with students, supporting them along their path to degree completion. There are learning opportunities at every turn.
cons: University departments and divisions are extremely territorial. Silos are at every turn and its hard to get people to genuinely synergize. In the end the students suffer.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Memphis, TN
pros: Really excellent, driven arts community with a musical theatre program on the rise. Very many helpful people in faculty/staff positions.
cons: Sometimes collaboration between departments can be scarce and with little to no reasoning. Hoping for more interdepartmental collaboration, at least within the arts, in the future.

review_title: Get out from your comfort zone
pros: Free tuition and helping young people
cons: Bad management... Having a PhD does not mean being smart and organized... Complete joke in term of management leadership...

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Memphis, TN
pros:
On Campus - Positions in every department
Flexible Scheduling - works around your class schdeule
Easy and low stress - most of the time not a whole lot is expected of you
cons:
A lot is dependent on your FASA, enrollment in the semester and budgeting
There's sometimes a lot of red tape office junk to get around 
Only allowed to work 20 hours a week

review_title: Working for the University of Memphis has been an awesome experience.
pros: Positive work environment, you feel like you're making a difference in others' lives, coworkers are easy to get along with
cons: Higher up administration tends to control your operations, your ideas aren't always heard because decisions are made higher up

review_title: Good place to work, expensive benefits.
pros: Flexible hours in most departments, good people to work with, great work environment
cons: Insurance is ridiculously expensive but that's typical of State of TN. Parking is paid per month which is ridiculous. Salaries aren't nearly enough for some jobs.

review_title: I had an amazing time working at the University of Memphis for four years in various departments.
pros: As a student they were always working around my schedule. I was promoted three times within three years so there is a lot of career growth.
cons: If you're not a student then you have a really strict schedule and there aren't many raises given to anyone.

pros: Easy pay, low responsibility. also you make your own hours and choose your own way to execute them. really great experience.
cons: No real cons. i would say salary was a problem you only make minimum wage here. and that is 7.25.

pros:
The environment was helping students and employee's.

pros: The one pro is that it is fairly easy to get hired as adjunct faculty, but is that best for students?
cons: As with most adjunct positions, the worth of the employee is far undervalued. We teach large classes and make a lot of money for the university. We should be better compensated for our work.

pros: The school itself is great, and the people who managed me were seasoned, experienced, respectful, and competent. Everyone took their job seriously, no matter what their title was. I was impressed by how much I learned on the job.
cons: Could not work more for them due to my college schedule

review_title: Great place for students to work.
pros: Great people, flexible work environment that allows students to complete course work, decent pay for the work you do. Fun work place
cons: Sometimes work is slow and there is not much to do and it can sometimes be boring. Not always a lot of guidance for assigned tasks.

pros: Good people.  Good benefits. Low cost of living in Memphis.
cons: UofM is an excellent option for first generation students but they aren't always very well prepared for the demands of university.  Money is tight for the Arts. We are always trying to do more with less.
